titleStmt.title: A Guide to the United States’ History of Recognition, Diplomatic, and Consular Relations, by Country, since 1776: Georgia
Georgia

sourceDesc.p: Researched and written by Christopher Morrison, February 2009

div.head: Summary
div.p: The United States recognized Georgia’s independence on December 25, 1991, when President George H.W. Bush announced the decision in an address to the nation regarding the dissolution of the Soviet Union. Georgia previously had been a constituent republic of the USSR.

div.head: Establishment of Diplomatic Relations, 1992.
div.p: Diplomatic relations were established on March 24, 1992, when President George H.W. Bush announced the decision in a press statement. “Statement by Press Secretary Fitzwater…,” March 24, 1992, Public Papers of the Presidents, George Bush, 1992-1993, Vol. 1, 502-503.

div.head: Establishment of the American Embassy in T’bilisi, 1992.
div.p: The American Embassy in T'bilisi was established April 23, 1992, with Carey Cavanaugh as Chargé d'Affaires ad interim.
